content.question: Read each question carefully. Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight. In an experiment, students release an object from rest on an incline. The incline makes an angle <math alttext="beta" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>β</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> with a horizontal tabletop, as shown above. The object has mass <math alttext="M" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and radius <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and rolls down the incline without slipping. The students run several trials to determine the rotational inertia <math alttext="I sub 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> of the object about its center. For each trial, the object is released from a different height <math alttext="h" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. The students use a video recording of the object to measure the speed <math alttext="v sub c m" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <msub> <mrow> <mi>v</mi> </mrow> <mrow> <mi>c</mi> <mi>m</mi> </mrow> </msub> </mrow> </mstyle> </math> of the center of mass of the object at the instant it reaches the bottom of the incline. (a) Using conservation of energy, derive an equation for <math alttext="h" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> as a function of <math alttext="v sum c m" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <msub> <mrow> <mi>v</mi> </mrow> <mrow> <mi>c</mi> <mi>m</mi> </mrow> </msub> </mrow> </mstyle> </math>. Express your answer in terms of <math alttext="M" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="beta" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>β</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="I sub 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, and physical constants, as appropriate.

frqParts.text: Read each question carefully. Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight. In an experiment, students release an object from rest on an incline. The incline makes an angle <math alttext="beta" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>β</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> with a horizontal tabletop, as shown above. The object has mass <math alttext="M" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and radius <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and rolls down the incline without slipping. The students run several trials to determine the rotational inertia <math alttext="I sub 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> of the object about its center. For each trial, the object is released from a different height <math alttext="h" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. The students use a video recording of the object to measure the speed <math alttext="v sub c m" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <msub> <mrow> <mi>v</mi> </mrow> <mrow> <mi>c</mi> <mi>m</mi> </mrow> </msub> </mrow> </mstyle> </math> of the center of mass of the object at the instant it reaches the bottom of the incline. (a) Using conservation of energy, derive an equation for <math alttext="h" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> as a function of <math alttext="v sum c m" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <msub> <mrow> <mi>v</mi> </mrow> <mrow> <mi>c</mi> <mi>m</mi> </mrow> </msub> </mrow> </mstyle> </math>. Express your answer in terms of <math alttext="M" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="beta" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>β</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="I sub 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, and physical constants, as appropriate.

(b) The students’ data are plotted on the graph below of <math alttext="h" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>h</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> as a function of <math alttext="v sub c m, end sub, squared" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msubsup><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>c</mi><mi>m</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msubsup></mrow></mstyle></math> for five different experimental runs. i. Draw a best-fit line to represent the data.

ii. Use your best-fit line to calculate the ratio <math alttext="the fraction I, over M R squared, end fraction" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>M</mi><mi>R</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math> for the object where <math alttext="I" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is the rotational inertia of the object.

Upon closer inspection of the video, the students observed that the object was slipping while rolling down the incline.(c) Will the total kinetic energy of the slipping object at the bottom of the incline be greater than, less than, or equal to the total kinetic energy at the bottom of the incline if the object was rolling without slipping?_____ Greater than _____ Less than _____ Equal toJustify your answer.
(d)i. Describe two changes to the experimental setup that would reduce the chance of the object slipping on the incline.
ii. Justify your reasoning for each.

(e) The experimental setup is now modified such that the object rolls without slipping. A cube also of mass <math alttext="M" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is released from rest from the same height, on the same incline, and at the same time as the object. It is observed that both objects reach the table at the same time.i. Is the magnitude of the linear acceleration of the cube greater than, less than, or equal to the linear acceleration of the cylinder?_____ Greater than _____ Less than _____ Equal toJustify your answer.

ii. Is the magnitude of the frictional force on the cube greater than, less than, or equal to the frictional force on the cylinder?_____Greater than _____ Less than ______ Equal toJustify your answer.

skill.text: 2.A: Derive a symbolic expression from known quantities by selecting and following a logical mathematical pathway.
